repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Land Management : Santa
            Catarina Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Land
            Management - Santa Catarina Project is highly satisfactory
            with highly likely sustainability, a high development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            the Borrower. Objectives and components were achieved with
            successful promotion of innovative participatory approaches,
            although the project did not succeed in raising farm income.
            The project itself, benefiting from an uncommon combination
            of factors, is unlikely to be replicable without adaptation.
            Lessons learned include: a) soil conservation investments
            must be based on technical changes that bring recognizable
            and early productivity benefits to farmers; b) extensive
            training, emphasizing group and participatory approaches,
            maybe necessary; c) skilled and creative project
            implementation staff, working closely with the Bank, can
            counter implementation constraints; d) improved land
            management can bring important external benefits; e) future
            project design should ensure the inclusion of adequate
            socio-economic and environmental monitoring activities; f)
            potential exists for microcatchment natural resource
            management projects to grow into more comprehensive rural
            development programs; g) microcatchment methodology and
            logic can create new forms of cooperation and trust; and h)
            extension staff play a key role in strategy implementation.

5078889.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
This project aims at supporting
            innovative technical approaches for economically viable
            investment in soil conservation. It's objectives are to
            increase agricultural production and farm incomes by
            promoting the adoption of sustainable forms of land
            management and soil and water conservation by Santa
            Caterina's farmers. This would improve farm
            profitability through cost effective and sustainable
            productivity gains, and better land use, as well as halting
            soil loss, the silting of river beds and dams, floods, the
            destruction of rural roads, pollution of water sources and
            depletion of natural resources. The project would support
            adaptive agricultural research, land use mapping, planning
            and monitoring, rural extension, an incentive program for
            land management, soil conservation and pollution control
            carried out by farmers and farmers groups, erosion control
            works along rural roads, forestry development and natural
            resource protection, project adminsitration, monitoring and
            evaluation, and training.
